items.title: Google DeepMind unveils new AI models for controlling robots
items.summary:
- Google DeepMind announced new AI models called [Gemini Robotics](https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/gemini-robotics-brings-ai-into-the-physical-world/?utm_source=keywordsnippet&utm_medium=referral) for real-world machine interaction.
- Demo videos show robots performing tasks like folding paper and responding to voice commands.
- Gemini Robotics is designed to generalize behaviors across various robotics hardware and connect visual inputs to actionable tasks.
- The system performed well in untrained environments and includes a slimmed-down version, Gemini Robotics-ER, for researchers.

items.title: The people in Elon Musk’s DOGE universe
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's ecosystem includes experienced engineers, advisors, and new talent from his companies like Tesla and SpaceX.
- Recent interactions between Musk's team and the U.S. federal government show a significant melding of private and public sectors.
- TechCrunch's investigation reveals details about DOGE's operations and its workforce, including recent staff cuts in response to federal budget constraints.
- Key figures include Elon Musk as DOGE Lead and various employees from Musk's ventures, highlighting a tight-knit network of professionals.
- The article outlines the roles of several individuals, illustrating Musk's influence and connections across the tech industry and government.

items.title: Browser Use, one of the tools powering Manus, is also going viral
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Manus, an AI platform by Butterfly Effect, has increased the visibility of the Browser Use tool.
- Daily downloads of Browser Use surged from 5,000 to 28,000 within a week after Manus was highlighted on social media.
- Browser Use facilitates autonomous web navigation for AI agents, allowing better interaction with websites.
- Co-creators Gregor Zunic and Magnus Müller launched Browser Use last year, envisioning it as foundational for web agents.
- Analysts predict significant growth in the AI agents market, potentially reaching $42 billion by 2029.

items.title: Browser User, one of the tools powering Manus, is also going viral
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Manus, an AI platform from Butterfly Effect, has increased the visibility of Browser Use.
- Browser Use saw daily downloads rise from 5,000 to 28,000 in one week, according to co-creator Gregor Zunic.
- Manus uses Browser Use for AI agents to execute tasks like navigating websites and filling forms.
- Zunic and co-creator Magnus Müller launched Browser Use last year, believing web agents would be significant in 2025.
- The tool helps AI interact with website elements and manage browser actions.
- Analysts predict significant market growth for AI agents, reaching $42 billion by 2029.

items.title: UK competition probe of mobile browsers finds Apple-Google duopoly is ‘anti-innovation’
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- A U.K. competition authority concluded that Apple and Google’s mobile browser policies hinder innovation and economic growth.
- Concerns highlighted include Apple’s WebKit mandatory usage on iOS, limiting competition for rival browsers.
- Google's revenue-sharing with Apple reduces financial incentives to compete, as they significantly profit from rival browser usage.

items.title: Donald Trump Jr. has been boosting MAGA-related startups
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Donald Trump Jr. joined VC firm 1789 Capital post-election and is monetizing the MAGA ecosystem.
- Investments include media, pharmaceuticals, firearms, and crypto, opposing ESG and DEI principles.
- 1789 Capital raised $500 million after Inauguration Day; aims for $1 billion for its first fund by mid-year.
- Notable investments include $15 million for Tucker Carlson’s media company and over $50 million in Musk's xAI and SpaceX.
- Trump Jr. serves on the board of three public companies and is trustee of Trump Media & Technology Group, the owner of Truth Social.

items.title: OpenStack comes to the Linux Foundation
items.author: Frederic Lardinois
items.summary:
- OpenStack, initially launched by Rackspace and NASA in 2010, is transitioning to the Linux Foundation via the Open Infrastructure Foundation.
- The Open Infrastructure Foundation aims to integrate with the Linux Foundation alongside major projects like Kubernetes and Linux.
- The collaboration is expected to bolster resources for development in a rapidly changing data center landscape influenced by AI and digital sovereignty.
- The OpenInfra Foundation’s community has grown by 15% with increased adoption for projects like OpenStack, Kata Containers, and StarlingX.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2025 tech layoffs
items.summary:
- In 2025, over 22,000 tech workers have been laid off, with 16,084 cuts in February alone.
- Major companies like NASA, Wayfair, and TikTok announced significant layoffs impacting hundreds of jobs.
- The tech industry is experiencing ongoing reductions as companies adapt to market conditions and automation.

items.title: Dapr’s Microservices Runtime Now Supports AI Agents
items.author: Frederic Lardinois
items.summary:
- Dapr, an open-source runtime for microservices, now introduces Dapr Agents to help developers build AI agents.
- Dapr's core feature of virtual actors allows for efficient processing of AI agent tasks, enabling scalability and resource efficiency.
- The project originated from Floki, which enhanced Dapr for AI use cases; it is now integrated into Dapr's framework.
- Dapr Agents can interface with popular model providers including AWS Bedrock and OpenAI, with support for local LLMs coming soon.
- Currently, Dapr Agents supports Python, with plans to include .NET, Java, JavaScript, and Go shortly.

items.title: Sakana claims its AI-generated paper passed peer review — but it’s a bit more nuanced than that
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Japanese startup Sakana claimed its AI-generated paper is the first to pass peer review, but with caveats.  
- Sakana used AI called The AI Scientist-v2 to generate and submit three papers to an ICLR workshop, with one accepted before withdrawal for transparency.  
- Critics note the acceptance rate is higher for workshops; many believe AI isn't ready to independently contribute to science yet.

items.title: Moonvalley releases a video generator it claims was trained on licensed content
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Moonvalley launches 'Marey', an AI video-generating model trained on openly licensed data.
- Marey offers customization options for in-scene movements, enabling nuanced control.
- The model generates HD clips up to 30 seconds and emphasizes lower legal risks compared to competitors.
- Moonvalley is making licensing arrangements to mitigate copyright concerns, similar to Adobe's approach.
- Concerns exist among artists about the impact of AI on jobs in the film and television industry.
- The company allows creators to remove their content from models and offers protective policies for users against copyright challenges.

items.title: Snap introduces AI Video Lenses powered by its in-house generative model
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Snapchat launches its first AI Video Lenses, powered by an in-house generative video model.
- Available exclusively to Snapchat Platinum subscribers for $15.99/month.
- Initial offerings include "Raccoon," "Fox," and "Spring Flowers" Lenses.
- New Lenses allow for AI-generated videos that save automatically to Memories.
- Snap aims to stay competitive against platforms like Instagram and TikTok with these innovative features.
- The company plans to introduce additional Lenses weekly.

items.title: Garantex administrator arrested in India under extradition law
items.author: Jagmeet Singh, Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
• Indian police arrested Aleksej Besciokov, co-founder of Garantex, under India’s extradition law.
• Arrest occurred in Varkala, Kerala, following a warrant issued by the Patiala House Court in New Delhi.
• U.S. Department of Justice charged Besciokov for facilitating money laundering linked to North Korean hackers.
• Besciokov will be transferred to Patiala Court to face unspecified extradition charges.
• Garantex has temporarily halted operations since the U.S. seizure of its websites and freezing of over $26 million in cryptocurrency assets.
• The exchange plans to compensate users for blocked assets through rehabilitation procedures once completed.

items.title: Why Onyx thinks its open-source solution will win enterprise search
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- Onyx offers an open-source internal enterprise search tool that connects to over 40 data sources including Salesforce and Google Drive.
- Co-founders Chris Weaver and Yuhong Sun aimed to solve the issue of information accessibility within companies.
- Onyx was previously known as Danswer and was launched in 2023, quickly gaining traction among enterprises like Netflix.
- The company has raised $10 million in seed funding to hire and develop premium features.
- Onyx competes with other startups and companies creating their own internal search solutions, such as Klarna's Kiki.
- The use of open-source is seen as key to scaling their solution across businesses globally.

items.title: Lithium-ion batteries are remaking Google’s data centers
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Google has installed 100 million lithium-ion cells across its data centers for backup power.
- Lithium-ion cells hold twice the power and occupy half the space of previous lead-acid batteries, allowing for more servers.
- The trend of battery utilization is expanding into various sectors, facilitating efficiency and performance improvements.

items.title: Project Europe, a new early stage fund, will back people under 25 to build the next tech titan
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Project Europe launches with $10 million to support tech entrepreneurs under 25.
- Successful applicants receive €200,000 to develop their ideas or startups.
- The fund aims to nurture young talent similar to initiatives like the Thiel Fellowship, without requiring college dropouts.
- Designed to address Europe's need for major tech companies and tackle funding gaps.
- In addition to funding, selected cohorts receive mentorship from experienced partners and access to a network of 119 investors.

items.title: Battery manufacturer Northvolt nears the end as it files for bankruptcy in Sweden
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Northvolt filed for bankruptcy in Sweden, impacting Europe's battery manufacturing efforts.
- The startup raised over $14 billion but failed to secure enough cash, burning through $100 million a month.
- Northvolt's challenges included rising costs, geopolitical instability, and supply chain issues, worsened by BMW canceling a $2 billion contract due to delays.
- The company laid off 1,600 employees and attempted to sell its Cuberg division assets to conserve cash.

items.title: How La Fourche, an online organic supermarket, is thriving after q-commerce’s bust
Pentera nabs $60M at a $1B+ valuation to build simulated network attacks to train security teams
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Pentera raises $60 million in Series D funding, valued at over $1 billion.
- The funding is aimed at mergers and acquisitions, and product development.
- Pentera provides simulations of network attacks to test security teams' responses, enhancing cybersecurity training.
- The startup has increased its customer base by 200% and annual recurring revenue by 300% over the last four years.
- Evolutions Equity Partners leads the funding round, with participation from Farallon Capital, Insight, K1, and Blackstone.
- The company aims to improve enterprise security testing through automated security validation, reducing alert noise and focusing on critical vulnerabilities.

items.title: Wolf Games, backed by ‘Law & Order’ creator, uses AI to create murder mystery games
items.author: Elliot Wolf, Andrew Adashek, Noah Rosenberg
items.summary:
- Elliot Wolf, son of ‘Law & Order’ creator Dick Wolf, co-founded Wolf Games to engage true crime fans.
- Wolf Games has raised $4.5 million in pre-seed funding for its project that uses AI to generate daily murder mystery games.
- The flagship title, Public Eye, allows players to solve crimes in a dystopian future with AI assistance.
- AI is used for creating storylines, interview clips, and maintaining character consistency.
- The game is set to launch this summer as a free-to-play model with optional in-app purchases.

items.title: Meta faces publisher copyright AI lawsuit in France
items.summary:
- Meta is being sued in France for allegedly training its AI models on copyrighted content without permission.
- The lawsuit was filed by several organizations, including the National Publishing Union and the National Union of Authors and Composers.
- This case marks a significant legal challenge for Meta, similar to ongoing litigation in the U.S. regarding AI training practices.

items.title: Ditto lands $82M to synchronize data from the edge to the cloud
items.summary:
- Ditto raised $82 million in Series B funding, valuing the company at $462 million.
- The funding will be used to grow the team and scale its core product, including partners with cloud vendors.
- Ditto offers a software development kit to enable connection between edge devices and the cloud, reducing reliance on centralized data processing.
- Major customers include the U.S. Air Force and several airlines, enhancing crew communication during flights.
- The company's growth is attributed to advancements in edge computing and increasing demand for AI-driven solutions.

items.title: Pokémon Go maker Niantic is selling its games division to Scopely for $3.5B
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Scopely has agreed to acquire Niantic's gaming division for $3.5 billion, totaling $3.85 billion with additional cash included.
- Niantic's games include Pokémon Go, Pikmin Bloom, Monster Hunter Now, and others, which will be transferred to Scopely.
- Niantic will focus on real-world 3D mapping through a new entity called Niantic Spatial, led by CEO John Hanke.
- Employees of Niantic's gaming division will join Scopely, which has a workforce of 2,300.
- Niantic will continue to operate Ingress Prime and Peridot under the new entity.
- Niantic aims to collect real-life location data and has plans for a large geospatial model using machine learning.

items.title: Scimplify raises $40M to help manufacturers access specialty chemicals
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Scimplify, an Indian startup, has raised $40 million in a Series B funding round co-led by Accel and Bertelsmann Investments.
- The funding will help expand Scimplify's footprint in the U.S. and new markets, with a post-money valuation of about $150 million.
- Scimplify connects manufacturers with specialty chemical makers through its platform, ATOMS, listing chemicals from over 5,000 factories in 10 countries.
- The startup serves 600 customers across more than 16 countries, vetting manufacturers and offering made-to-order chemicals.
- Plans include regional expansion, targeting new industry segments, and potentially acquiring chemical factories.

items.title: Salesforce to invest $1B in Singapore to boost adoption of AI
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- Salesforce plans to invest $1 billion in Singapore over the next five years to enhance its AI agent development platform, Agentforce.
- The investment aims to address labor shortages in Singapore and create digital workforces combining humans and AI agents.
- This initiative follows previous $500 million investments in Saudi Arabia and Argentina to expand AI services.
- Salesforce has been investing in Singapore for nearly 20 years, with key clients including Singapore Airlines, Grab, and FairPrice Group.
- The company has signed a deal with Singapore Airlines to integrate Agentforce into their customer case management system.

items.title: North Korean government hackers snuck spyware on Android app store
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- North Korean hackers uploaded spyware (KoSpy) on the Google Play app store.
- The campaign is suspected to target individuals, possibly in South Korea.
- KoSpy collects sensitive data like SMS, call logs, location, and media from devices.
- The malware was downloaded over 10 times before being removed by Google.
- Lookout, the cybersecurity firm, detailed the findings in a report shared with TechCrunch.
- Google responded by removing the identified apps and deactivating associated projects.

items.title: Elea AI Targets Pathology Labs to Boost Healthcare Productivity
items.summary:
- Elea AI focuses on improving productivity in pathology labs using AI.
- Its system replaces outdated information systems with an AI operating system that automates workflows, significantly reducing report generation time.
- After six months of use, labs saw reporting time cut to two days.
- The platform features speech-to-text transcription and a unique integration into lab processes.
- Elea aims for international expansion, particularly targeting the U.S. market, after a successful launch in Germany.
- The startup raised €4 million in seed funding and plans to pursue a Series A round.

items.title: Uber terminates Foodpanda Taiwan acquisition, citing regulatory hurdles
Jio announces deal to bring Starlink to India just hours after similar Airtel  partnership
Tata Technologies’ data leaked by ransomware gang
Spotify says its payouts are getting better, but artists still disagree
Google has given Anthropic more funding than previously known, show new filings
Meta is reportedly testing in-house chips for AI training
items.summary:
• Meta is testing an in-house chip for AI training to reduce dependency on Nvidia.
• The chip was manufactured in collaboration with TSMC and is designed for AI-specific tasks.
• Meta plans to pilot a small deployment and scale production based on test results.
• Previous custom AI chips were used for running models, not training them.
• Meta's capital expenditure for the year is $65 billion, largely for Nvidia GPUs, indicating significant potential cost savings if in-house chips succeed.

items.title: Bolt CEO Ryan Breslow explains his troubled $30M personal loan, announces new ‘super app’
items.author: Charles Rollet, Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Ryan Breslow, Bolt's CEO, discussed a controversial $30 million personal loan that led to legal issues and his temporary ousting.
- Breslow plans to launch a new ‘super app’ combining one-click checkout features across various services like crypto and financial products.
- The legal dispute began in 2023 when investor Activant sued Breslow for borrowing $30 million and defaulting, resulting in a settlement where Bolt repurchased shares for $37 million.

items.title: Trump says he will label violence against Tesla as domestic terrorism
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- President Trump announced he will classify violence against Tesla dealerships as domestic terrorism.
- Protests known as "Tesla Takeovers" are occurring globally, with incidents of vandalism and violence, including Molotov cocktails.
- Tesla's stock and sales have significantly declined, attributed to Musk’s political ties and controversies.
- Trump emphasized a strict response to such violence, reinforcing protections for Tesla as a major American company.
- The definition of violence remains unclear, raising concerns about labeling peaceful protests negatively.
- Critics view Musk’s actions as benefiting from government contracts, despite the controversies surrounding layoffs within government agencies.

items.title: The New Yorker has finally embraced modernity
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- The New Yorker has updated its copyediting guidelines to adopt more contemporary internet-related styles.
- The changes include moving away from archaic terms like "e-mails" and "in box."
- The magazine will retain its commitment to the diaeresis in spellings such as "coöperative."
- The decision was made after discussions among editors, including former copy editors, in January.
- The updates aim to modernize the magazine while maintaining some of its traditional quirks.

items.title: IBM’s CEO doesn’t think AI will replace programmers anytime soon
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- IBM CEO Arvind Krishna emphasizes the importance of global trade for U.S. growth, stating that a 10% increase in global trade can lead to a 1% increase in local GDP.
- Krishna believes AI will increase programmer productivity, with an expectation that only 20-30% of code will be written by AI, contrary to predictions of 90%.
- He likens the concerns over AI replacing jobs to past fears about calculators and Photoshop, arguing that AI is a tool that enhances productivity rather than a direct replacement for programmers.

items.title: Y Combinator founders raising less money signal a ‘vibe shift,’ VC says
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Silicon Valley sees a shift as AI enables startups to thrive with smaller teams and less funding.
- Investor Terrence Rohan notes a change in mindset among Y Combinator founders, preferring to raise less capital.
- Reduced funding allows founders to retain a larger ownership stake and maintain control.
- Some investors, like Parker Conrad, argue that less capital could hinder growth and competitiveness.
- Examples include Anysphere and ElevenLabs reaching significant annual revenues with minimal staff.
- The article highlights a trend of founders being more cautious about venture capital and its consequences.

items.title: Apple fixes new security flaw used in ‘extremely sophisticated attack’
items.summary:
- Apple released patches for a zero-day bug in WebKit, affecting Safari and other apps.
- The flaw allowed hackers to escape WebKit's protective sandbox, potentially compromising targeted devices.
- The patch was issued for various Apple devices including Macs, iPhones, iPads, Safari, and the Vision Pro headset on March 11, 2025.
- The attack targeted devices running software prior to iOS 17.2, though no specifics about the hackers or targets were disclosed.
- This is at least the second mention of an 'extremely sophisticated attack' by Apple in recent times regarding vulnerabilities, with no evidence linking the two incidents.

items.title: OpenAI says it has trained an AI that’s ‘really good’ at creative writing
items.summary:
- OpenAI has trained a new AI model that excels at creative writing according to CEO Sam Altman.
- The model was demonstrated with a prompt to write a metafictional literary short story about AI and grief.
- The company has primarily focused on predictably structured applications before this shift to creative writing, suggesting significant improvements in generative capabilities.

items.title: DOGE axes CISA ‘red team’ staffers amid ongoing federal cuts
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) has laid off over a hundred employees from CISA, including red team staffers.
- Layoffs occurred in late February and early March, with affected employees cut immediately without prior warning.
- More than 80 employees in continuous monitoring and 30-50 in incident response were affected, marking the third known round of layoffs at CISA since January 20.

items.title: Podcast app Pocket Casts makes its web player free
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Pocket Casts, a podcast app owned by Automattic, has made its web player free to use.
- Users can stream episodes without a subscription or account, but can create a free account for additional features.
- The company's Pocket Casts Plus subscription offers extra tools and customization options.
- Unlike competitors, Pocket Casts does not use AI-driven content suggestions, promoting user choice instead.
- Free streaming will also be available on Pocket Casts’ Mac and Windows apps, challenging services like Apple Podcasts.

items.title: Flower Labs’ launches a new service that automatically switches from local to cloud AI
Yet another AI robotics firm lands major funding, as Dexterity closes latest round
Geothermal could power nearly all new data centers through 2030
OpenAI launches new tools to help businesses build AI agents
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- OpenAI released new tools for developers and businesses to build AI agents using its own AI models.
- The tools are part of the new Responses API, replacing the old Assistants API.
- The hype around AI agents has increased, but technical challenges remain for adoption and usability.
- New offerings include highly accurate web search models (GPT-4o search and GPT-4o mini search) and a file search utility for company databases.
- OpenAI introduced an open-source Agents SDK for integrating models and monitoring AI agent activities.
- OpenAI aims for 2025 to be a pivotal year for AI agents in the workforce.

items.title: Mark Cuban says AI is ‘never the answer,’ it’s a ‘tool’
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Mark Cuban spoke at the SXSW conference about AI's role in aiding small businesses.
- He emphasized that AI should serve as a tool, not an answer by itself.
- Cuban encouraged entrepreneurs to learn about AI to leverage its potential in business.

items.title: Hugging Face expands its LeRobot platform with training data for self-driving machines
Waymo expands its robotaxi service across Silicon Valley
Virtual physical therapists Hinge Health files for IPO, estimated to raise $500M
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Hinge Health is a company focused on treating chronic musculoskeletal conditions digitally and has filed for an IPO.
- The company aims to raise up to $500 million, although share pricing has not yet been announced.
- In 2024, Hinge's revenue was $390 million, a 33% increase from the previous year, with narrowed net losses of $11.9 million.
- Hinge employs advanced wearable sensors and computer vision technology monitored by a professional team to help reduce MSK pain.
- Previously valued at $6.2 billion in October 2021, Hinge has raised a total of $828 million in venture capital.
- Insight Partners and Atomico are the largest outside shareholders, holding 19% and 15% respectively.
